title: Issue 318: Enable users to read from Tail of Stream.
body:
Note: This includes the pyo3 upgrade changes from PR: https://github.com/pravega/pravega-client-rust/pull/321. 

**Change log description**  

- Enable a Stream meta client that enables users to

- Externalized ReaderGroupConfig that can be used to read multiple Streams from their StreamCuts.

- Ensure Python APIs allow users to read from the TAIL of a Stream.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #318 
Fixes #307 

**What the code does**  
1. Enable a Stream meta client that enables users to
    a. Fetch a StreamCut pointing to the current Head of a Stream.
    b. Fetch a StreamCut pointing to the current Tail of a Stream.
    c. Check if the Stream is sealed.

2. Enable ReaderGroup to take the starting StreamCut postion to read for Stream under it.
3. Externalized ReaderGroupConfig that can be used to read multiple Streams from their StreamCuts.
4. Ensure Python API allows a way to specify the ReaderGroupConfig to read from a Stream.
4. Ensure Python APIs allow users to read from the TAIL of a Stream.

**How to verify it**  
All the existing and newly added tests should pass.

body:

- Increase API support from python 3.6.x to 3.9

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #306
Fixes #320 

**What the code does**  
- Upgrade pyo3 to 0.14.5
- Use https://crates.io/crates/pyo3-asyncio crate to convert RUST futures to Python futures.
- Ensure the python bindings now are supported from Python 3.6.x to python 3.9
- Ensure the python tests run on Python 3.6.x

**How to verify it**  
All the existing and newly added tests should continue to pass.

title: Issue 313: Enable ByteStreamAPI for PravegaPython bindings.
body:
**Change log description**  
Enable ByteStream API for Pravega Python bindings.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #313 

**What the code does**  
Create a Binary I/O representation for a Pravega Stream in Python bindings. This implements the APIs provided by [docs.python.org/3/library/io.html#io.IOBase](https://docs.python.org/3/library/io.html#io.IOBase)

```python
import pravega_client;
manager=pravega_client.StreamManager("tcp://127.0.0.1:9090")

# Create a writer against an already created Pravega scope and Stream.
byte_stream=manager.create_byte_stream("scope", "stream");

# write bytes into the Pravega Stream. It returns the current write offset
byte_stream.write(b"bytes")
5

# seek to the specified read offset.
byte_stream.seek(2, 0)

#  read data into a buffer, it returns the number of bytes read.
buf=bytearray(5)
byte_stream.readinto(buf)
3

# print the buffer.
buf
bytearray(b'tes\x00\x00')

# truncate a byte stream at offset 2
byte_stream.truncate(2)

# fetch the current head offset of the Stream
byte_stream.current_head_offset()
2

# fetch the current tail offset of the Pravega Stream.
byte_stream.current_tail_offset()
5
```

Note: This fixes the cross compilation build issue with `cross` in the Github action.

**How to verify it**  
All the existing and newly added tests should pass.

title: Issue 267: Remove runtime drop error message
body:
**Change log description**  
Remove runtime drop error message.
Upgrade tonic version to 0.5, prost version to 0.8 as prost version 0.7 is having problem with `rustc 1.56.0-nightly (50171c310 2021-09-01)` [ref](https://github.com/tokio-rs/prost/issues/526).

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #267 #308 #253

**What the code does**  
ClientFactory is the only place that contains the Runtime and it cannot be cloned, so there is only one place that's holding the runtime now.
Make another struct ClientFacotryAsync that holds `Runtime::Handle`, which can be cloned and used in async context.

**How to verify it**  
Test should pass

title: Issue 310 : Enable inflight event configuration on Python writer API.
body:
**Change log description**  
- Enable a configurable number of inflight events to be written by the Python writer.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #310 

**What the code does**  
- Create a oneshot receiver holder which tracks multiple oneshot receivers tracking every inflight event.
- Users will now be able to specify the max number of inflight events that can be configured for the Python writer.
```rust
  pub fn create_writer(
        &self,
        scope_name: &str,
        stream_name: &str,
        max_inflight_events: usize,
    ) -> PyResult<StreamWriter> {..}
```
- A flush () API has been enabled for the Python Writer which ensures all the inflight events are persisted.

``` rust
///
/// Flush all the inflight events into Pravega Stream.
/// This will ensure all the inflight events are completely persisted on the Pravega Stream.
///
pub fn flush(&mut self) {...}
```



**How to verify it**  
All the existing and newly added tests should pass.

title: Issue 232: Create command line app which reads from stdin and publishes to Pravega
body:
**Change log description**  
- Command line app which reads from stdin and publishes it to the configured Pravega Stream.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #232

**What the code does**  

Implements a command-line app that reads from stdin and publishes it to the configured Pravega Stream.
```
cat ./event.log | ./pravegctl write scope1/stream1
```

App capabilities
```
PravegaCtl 0.0.1
Utility to interact with Pravega

USAGE:
    pravegactl [FLAGS] [OPTIONS] <SUBCOMMAND>

FLAGS:
    -a, --enable-auth    Enable authorization, default is false
    -h, --help           Prints help information
    -V, --version        Prints version information

OPTIONS:
    -u, --controller-uri <controller-uri>    To enable TLS use uri of the format tls://ip:port [default:
                                             tcp://127.0.0.1:9090]

SUBCOMMANDS:
    create-scope            Create Scope
    create-stream           Create Stream with a fixed segment count
    help                    Prints this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)
    list-scopes             List Scopes
    list-streams            List Streams under a scope
    list-streams-for-tag    List Streams for a tag, under a scope
    write                   Write events from STDIN. Each line is treated as an individual event

```

Update the workflow to generate artifacts for the following targets
* x86_64-unknown-linux-musl
* arm-unknown-linux-gnueabihf
* x86_64-apple-darwin
* x86_64-pc-windows-msvc
* x86_64-pc-windows-gnu
* i686-pc-windows-msvc

The generated artifacts are uploaded to the workflow run. e.g: https://github.com/pravega/pravega-client-rust/actions/runs/1089026393#artifacts


**How to verify it**  
All the existing tests should continue to pass.

title: Issue 295: Fix multiple thread conditional appending
body:
**Change log description**  
Fix race condition in multi thread conditional append.
Remove sync API in byte API to make it consistent. 
Remove previous fix #209 since Pravega side issue has been fixed. See issue #198.
Use custom `pravega::error::Error` instead of `std::io::Error` for write result so caller can call match on the error type to check if ConditionalCheckFailure happens.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #295 #198

**What the code does**  
Current impl is to only hold the latest EventHandle. The fix is to hold all the EventHandles and checks each one to see if there is a ConditionalCheckFailure.

If ConditionalCheckFailure happens, reactor will set it status to be `need_reset` and reject all new requests since caller may send append before receiving the failure. So caller need to manually call `reset` before continue the append.
**How to verify it**

title: Issue 280: Enable Stream tags for Python bindings.
body:
**Change log description**  
- Enable Stream tags for Python bindings.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #280 

**What the code does**  
- Enable passing of Stream scaling policy and Retention policy for python bindings.
- Enable Stream Tag APIs on python bindings.

```python

# create a stream with stream scaling is enabled with data rate as 10kbps, scaling factor as 2 and initial segments as 1
scalingpolicy = StreamScalingPolicy.auto_scaling_policy_by_data_rate(10, 2, 1)
stream_manager.create_stream_with_policy(scope_name=scope, stream_name="testStream1", scaling_policy=scalingpolicy)
# By default retention policy is disabled.

# update stream with retentionpolicy and tags.
##retention policy of 10GB
retentionpolicy = StreamRetentionPolicy.by_size(10*1024*1024 * 1024)
stream_manager.update_stream_with_policy(scope, "testStream1", scalingpolicy, retentionpolicy, tags=['t1', 't2'])

# fetch stream tags for the given Stream
tags = stream_manager.get_stream_tags(scope, "testStream1")
```

**How to verify it**  
All the existing and newly added tests should pass.

**What the code does**

**How to verify it**

title: Issue 234: Implement index stream
body:
**Change log description**  
Add support to the index stream.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #234 

**What the code does**  
***Naming***
* Record: Fixed size(4KB) event written to the stream. A record contains: type code(4 bytes), entries length(4 bytes), data length(4 bytes) entries, entries and data.
* Field: A key value pair(&'static str, u64) . Key is a string that user defines, value is a u64 that is monotonically increasing.
* Fields: A set of field. User specifies a label struct that has a number of fields, the name of the field is the entry key and the value is entry value. This impl provides a procedure macro called label that can parse the struct to an array of entries. 

***Index writer***:
* append(data, label): append the given label and data to the stream. It is guaranteed that the new label has all the exsiting entries and their values are not less than the current values.
* append_conditionally(data, label, condition_label): same as above, plus a given condition label that has to be exactly the same as the latest label in the stream
* flush(): flush appends
* truncate(offset): truncate to a offset.

***Index reader***:
* search_offset(entry: (key, value)): search for the offset of the first record that has a matching key and value that is equal to or larger than the target value 
* read(start_offset, end_offset): read a slice of a stream. When end_offset is u64::MAX, it means tail read.
* first_record(): first readable record
* last_record(): latest record
* head_offset():
* last_offset():


**How to verify it**  
Tests should pass.

title: Issue 256:  Enable stream tag API on the RUST client.
body:
**Change log description**  
- Enable Stream Tag API on the RUST client.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #256 

**What the code does**  
- Update the Controller proto file with the latest version of the Controller.
- Enable Tag related APIs on the RUST client.
The following APIs have been enabled.

```rust

    /**
     * API to fetch the Stream Configuration of a Stream.
     */
    async fn get_stream_configuration(&self, stream: &ScopedStream) -> ResultRetry<StreamConfiguration>;

    /**
     * API to fetch the Tags for a Stream.
     */
    async fn get_stream_tags(&self, stream: &ScopedStream) -> ResultRetry<Option<Vec<String>>>;

    /**
     * API to list streams associated with the given tag under a given scope and continuation token.
     * Use the pravega_controller_client::paginator::list_streams_for_tag to paginate over all the streams.
     */
    async fn list_streams_for_tag(
        &self,
        scope: &Scope,
        tag: &str,
        token: &CToken,
    ) -> ResultRetry<Option<(Vec<ScopedStream>, CToken)>>;
```
- Enable CLI option to create Stream with tags and list streams with a tag under a given scope.
```
osboxes@osboxes:~$ ./controller-cli list-streams-for-tag --help
controller-cli-list-streams-for-tag 0.2.0
List Streams for a tag, under a scope

USAGE:
    controller-cli list-streams-for-tag <scope-name> <tag>

FLAGS:
    -h, --help       Prints help information
    -V, --version    Prints version information

ARGS:
    <scope-name>    Scope Name
    <tag>           Tag Name

```


**How to verify it**  
All the existing and newly added tests should pass.
Integration tests have been created to run against the latest version of Pravega.

title: Issue 247: Accept scheme in controller URI
body:
**Change log description**  
* allow scheme to be included in PravegaNodeUri
* changes ClientConfigBuilder to automatically set `is_tls_enabled = true` when uri scheme is 'tls'
* allows tls scheme to be used with StreamManager Python client when tls_enabled default value (false) is used

**Purpose of the change**  

Fixes #247 

**What the code does**  
changes to shared/lib
* accepts schemes in PravegaNodeUri
* added PravegaNodeUriParseError
* added PravegaNodeUri::is_well_formed static method
* added PravegaNodeUri::uri_parts_from_string static method
* changed existing methods to use uri_parts_from_string

changes to config/lib
* added default builder for `ClientConfigBuilder::is_tls_enabled`
* altered `ClientConfigBuilder::extract_trustcerts` to also call `default_is_tls_enabled` (builder order of operations calls extract_trustcerts before default_is_tls_enabled)
* added `ClientConfigBuilder::validate` to check for conflicts between uri scheme and `.is_tls_enabled()`
* removed duplicate `builder(setter(into))`  from controller_uri because its already set at the struct level

changes to python_binding/stream_manager
* changed `StreamManager` constructor, if `tls_enabled = false` then rely on the scheme from `controller_uri` to set `is_tls_enabled`
* updated sample usage


**How to verify it**  

* rust tests have been added 
* was not able to test python changes due to issues with maturin

**Comments**

The only uri scheme this code specifically tests for is `tls`. It should probably only allow `tcp, tls` schemes (but see my outstanding question on #247)

Some existing PravegaNodeUri methods panic if the uri is malformed. I added `is_well_formed` static method so that library consumers could test a uri before building a clientconfig.  This approach seems a bit dodgy. Perhaps changing PravegaNodeUri to a struct not derived from String could improve this, but I think that would require more changes to the library.

If we want true backwards compatibility with the python client, we may wish to change StreamManager `tls_enabled` arg to `PyAny` type, then set the default python arg to either `None` or a sentinel object that can make it clear whether or not the python caller provided a value for `tls_enabled`

This is my first rust code. Some of the changes don't look quite right. I considered using Regex but its currently only used in the auth crate, so didn't seem worth pulling into this one.

title: Issue 264: Manually validate the connection
body:
**Change log description**  
Fix the `payLoadLengthTooLong` issue.
Prevent connections that has stale data from being dropped back into the pool.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #264

**What the code does**  
Marks connection as invalid when created. `ClientConnection` later validates the connection when it consumes all the data in the connection. This way we can be sure that every connection that's dropped back into the pool is clean and it doesn't have corrupted data.

**How to verify it**  
Tests should pass, also need to verify in the gstreamer experiment.

title: Issue 243, 244: Support multiple certs and allow user to pass keycloak as json string
body:
**Change log description**  
1. `ClientConfig` can now take multiple certs. Users cam put certs in a directory and pass that directory to the `ClientConfig`.
2. User can now pass keycloak json string directly to the `ClientConfig` by using `Credentials::keycloak_by_json_string(json);`

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #243 #244 

**What the code does**  
1. Instead of reading from a file to get a cert, we read all the files in a given directory and add all the certs to the config.
2. Have a new method `Credentials::keycloak_by_json_string` that takes the json string as input. Also cache the json string so we don't need to read from files everytime when refreshing. 

**How to verify it**  
Tests should pass

title: Issue 262: support multiple segments in byte stream
body:
**Change log description**  
support multiple segments in byte stream

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #262 

**What the code does**  
Add a `Option<ScopedSegment>` field in the `PendingEvent`. 
If the `Option` is not `None`, then `selector` will directly fetch the writer from the map using `segment` as a key.

**How to verify it**  
Tests should pass

title: Issue 200: Drop on EventReader should automatically invoke reader offline API.
body:
**Change log description**  
Drop on EventReader should invoke readerOffline.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #200 

**What the code does**  
Drop on EventReader should invoke `reader_offline()`.

This is useful in scenarios where the Python user forgets to invoke reader offline. A scenario described in #257 is one instance of this.

With this change, `reader_offline()` is automatically invoked when the object is destructed.
```
In [11]: r1=rg.create_reader("r1")
May 14 18:54:41.627  INFO pravega_client::stream_reader_group: Creating reader "r1" under reader group "rg2"
May 14 18:54:41.627  INFO pravega_client::event::reader_group_state: Adding reader Reader { name: "r1" } to reader group

In [12]: r1=rg.create_reader("r2")
May 14 18:54:47.361  INFO pravega_client::stream_reader_group: Creating reader "r2" under reader group "rg2"
May 14 18:54:47.361  INFO pravega_client::event::reader_group_state: Adding reader Reader { name: "r2" } to reader group
May 14 18:54:47.369  INFO pravega_client::event::reader: putting reader r1 offline
```

**How to verify it**  
All the existing tests should continue to pass.

title: Issue 245: Retry when controller receives unauthenticated error

**Purpose of the change**

**What the code does**  
Reset the controller connection and refresh the auth token when `Unauthenticated` happened.

title: Issue 241: Reorg code
body:
**Change log description**  
Reorg the code.

* Move internal file `raw_client`, `segment_metadata`, `segment_selector`, `reactor`, `segment_writer` to a new module `segment` and remove `segment` prefix in their names.
* Move `event_stream_writer`, `event_reader` , `reader_group` related files and `transaction` module into a new module 'event'.
* Move `bytestream` to a new module `byte`.
* Move `synchronizer`, `tablemap` to a new module `sync`.
* Move `trace`, `metric` to a new module `util`.
* Delete `error` file and move individual error into related files.
* Rename `event_stream_writer` to `event_writer`.
* Rename `transactional_event_stream_writer` to `transaction_event_writer`.
* Rename `byte_stream_writer` and `byte_stream_reader` to `byte_writer` and `byte_reader`.
* Rename `table_synchronizer` to `synchronizer`.


**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #241 #246 #240 

**What the code does**  

**How to verify it**

title: Issue 225: Implement list streams controller API
Issue 238: Fix the automated python bindings publish workflow.
body:
**Change log description**

Prepare v0.1.0 release

title: Issue 223: Fix connection leak
body:
**Change log description**  
This PR adds a shutdown handle to PrefetchRead and prevents it from recycling connections.

The reason is that the background task of prefetching read could hang for a long time if the fetching offset is at the end of stream. If byte stream reader calls `seek`, then PrefetchRead will be destroyed and this background task is left unattended and a connection is leaked. 

However, adding shutdown hook itself is not enough. The connection could have stale message from the server when recycled back to pool. And anyone use that connection from the pool will have to deal with this stale message which is annoying. 

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #223

**What the code does**  
Adds a shutdown hook and prevents PrefetchRead from recycling connections.

**How to verify it**  
Manually verify that no connection leaked when calling `seek`.

title: Issue 228: Fix acquire segment
body:
**Change log description**  
Change `recv` to `try_recv` in `acquire_segment` method.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #228 

**What the code does**  
`recv` will block forever if there is no slice for that reader. Use `try_recv` to let method return and caller can re-enter the method to acquire new segments.

**How to verify it**  
Test should pass

title: Perf improvement: Avoid a copy of the routing_key string on every write.
body:
Signed-off-by: Tom Kaitchuck <tom.kaitchuck@emc.com>

**Change log description**  
 Avoid a copy of the routing_key string on every write.

**What the code does**  
Borrows the ScopedSegment rather than performing a clone of the string.

title: Add byte stream reader benchmark and improve read performance
body:
**Change log description**  

Adds byte stream reader benchmark.
Removes `drain` operation as it involves memcpy that decreases the read performance significantly.

Improved performance snapshot:
10K ops, 100 Bytes payload
write: 20ms,
read: 5ms

title: Issue 198: ConditionalCheckFailed due to reconnection
body:
**Change log description**  

A false `ConditionalCheckFailed` returned due to reconnection. 

What happens is that when client sends an Event `e` to server and server has already accepted `e`, a reconnection is triggered before client receives the ack reply. The `e` is sent to server again due to reconnection so the ConditionalCheckFailed is returned since `e` has already been accepted before.

The temporary fix for this issue it to check if a reconnection happened right before receiving `ConditionalCheckFailed`. If it is then this error could be a false alarm and we can ignore it. However, this is not 100% guaranteed since another writer could write some data to the segment right at the reconnection session of our writer, and in that case the `ConditionalCheckFailed` is true. Right now there is no good way to tell unless we check the data in segment. But based on the discussion in #198, the temporary fix is probably good enough.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #198 

NOTE: more investigations are needed, please ignore it for now

title: Issue 197: Reader Benchmark
body:
**Change log description**  
Enable a Reader Benchmark.

**Purpose of the change**  
Fixes #197 

**What the code does**  
The benchmark uses a mock server to simulate a Segment store that returns 100KB of data over the loopback (127.0.0.1)  interface. All the calls to the TableSynchronizer and the controller are mocked.

The reader based benchmark can be executed via the following command.
`cargo bench -- read`

**How to verify it**  
Verified that the benchmark works and the reports are generated in the target folder.

title: Issue 192: Keycloak support
body:
**Change log description**  
Support keycloak

**Purpose of the change**  
Fix #192 

**What the code does**  
If auth is enabled and keycloak is chosen, client will first try to read a `keycloak.json` file. After that Pravega Rust client will issue two POST requests to the keycloak server, the first POST request is to obtain an access token, so the Pravega Rust client can be authenticated and becomes a keycloak client. The second POST request is to use the access token to ask for permissions on behalf a user, which is the Rust client itself. The token returned from the second POST is called RPT(relying party token), with this token anyone can access to the given resources, which in our case, is just the Pravega controller. The RPT token is used by controller client in Rust client for authentication and authorization.

**How to verify it**  
Starts a SDP cluster and runs an application that uses the Pravega Rust client.
